topics.Architecture: Microservices, DDD, containere (Docker, Rocket...), event-sourcing, asynchronous services, fault tolerant systems, REST, dependency injection, web services without frameworks, web services without app servers, in-memory computing
topics.Mobile: Mobile first design, testing tools, multi-platform development, Apple Watch, iOS, Android, Windows Mobile
topics.Devops: Infrastructure as code, provisioning, continuous deployment
topics.Persistence: NoSQL, SQL, big data, cloud, grid
topics.Test code: Writing good tests, testing tools, continuous testing, TDD, BDD
topics.Programming: Paradigms, parallelism, typing, languages (C#, F#, Scala, Elixir, Clojure, etc.)
topics.Tools: Version control, build systems, SaaS, analysis (Sonar, R, etc.)
topics.Platforms and other: Cloud, Internet of Things, CMS, CRM, Office 365, EPiServer

submissions: A farewell to JavaScript? Looking at Scala.js

collections.time: 19:40-19:45 Dinner groups meet in the lobby

collections.details: Erik Amundrud, Business Area Manager, Knowit Solutions Norway

object_relation_mapping_kjapt_og_enkelt.speaker: Erlend Rommetveit
object_relation_mapping_kjapt_og_enkelt.title: Object Relation Mapping gjort kjapt og enkelt
object_relation_mapping_kjapt_og_enkelt.description: Hvilket ORM passer best for deg? Prioriterer du hastighet, enkelhet, eller er det funksjonalitet som er viktigst? Denne talken er en kort sammenligning av tre ulike biblioteker for .NET: Entity Framework, NPoco, og Dapper. Derav den f√∏rste er et fullverdig ORM med mye innebygd funksjonalitet, mens de andre er s√•kalte Micro-ORM-biblioteker der hastighet har hovedfokus.

gothenburg_startup_hack.speaker: Max Witt
gothenburg_startup_hack.title: Gothenburg Startup Hack - Bringing the community together
gothenburg_startup_hack.description: Gothenburg Startup Hack is an annual event that since 2014 has brought the technical and entrepreneurial communities together to create amazing ideas, prototypes and ventures, all in one day. In 2017, Knowit Systems Development was one of the five major sponsors that made the event possible. I'd like to tell you about the event and how it brings inspiration to seasoned professionals, promotes talented students and facilitates cross-disciplinary collaboration.

javascript_state_of_affairs.speaker: Christoffer Eliesen
javascript_state_of_affairs.title: Javascript: State of Affairs
javascript_state_of_affairs.description: Do you want to be a front end developer? Do you know what you‚Äôre getting yourself into? Well I do, and in this talk I present an overview of the complex beast that awaits you in the web.

reklamefri_web_2020.speaker: Eirik Nesje
reklamefri_web_2020.title: Reklamefri Web 2020
reklamefri_web_2020.description: Ingen liker reklame eller betalingsmurer. Hvordan skal nyhetsnettsider som VG livn√¶re seg, n√• som vi lever i Adblock-√¶raen? Finnes det et alternativ som ikke er forstyrrende for brukeren og samtidig gir en b√¶rekraftig inntekt for innholdsskaperne? Vi skal utforske mining av kryptovaluta i nettleseren og vise hvordan et nettsted kan f√• en stabil inntekt ved √• bruke klienten sin datakraft. Denne talken vil ta for seg fordeler og ulemper ved dette, samt se p√• konkrete implementasjoner av teknologien.

maskinl√¶ring_parkeringsgebyrklager_oslo.speaker: Joakim Lehn
maskinl√¶ring_parkeringsgebyrklager_oslo.title: Maskinl√¶ring for Parkeringsgebyrklager i Oslo kommune
maskinl√¶ring_parkeringsgebyrklager_oslo.description: I sommer ble det utviklet en maskinl√¶ringsalgoritme som skal predikere utfallet av klager p√• parkeringsgebyr, form√•let med denne algoritmen var at den skulle effektivisere behandlingen av klager. I denne lyntalen vil jeg g√• gjennom hvordan vi gikk frem for √• lage l√∏sningen og en kort oppsummering av resultatene.

set_up_a_microservice_architecture.speaker: Marit Hellest√∏
set_up_a_microservice_architecture.title: How to set up a microservice architecture?
set_up_a_microservice_architecture.description: Being relatively new to working on backend projects I‚Äôve been thrown into one with an architecture based on the microservice principles. This caused me to ask how one would go about setting up such a structure. Would one choose to build everything from scratch, in terms of service discovery and infrastructure, or would one use existing frameworks to get things up and running, in which case what would one have to set up manually? A google search for microservice frameworks does not return a small number of links. And in a jungle of tools I decided to try some out. Since I‚Äôm working with a .NET project I decided to limit the frameworks I tested to .NET compatible ones. In this talk I will share some of my conclusions after this experiment, and hopefully this can trigger a discussion base on others experiences and potential pitfalls with whatever solution they have used.

web_page_api_aws_lambda.speaker: Runar Furenes
web_page_api_aws_lambda.title: Turn someone else‚Äôs web page into an API with AWS Lambda
web_page_api_aws_lambda.description: Do you frequently use some website because it has valuable information not found elsewhere? Wouldn‚Äôt it be great to have access to the same data, served as JSON through an open API, without setting up any servers? In this presentation I walk through how to create such an API with Python and AWS Lambda.

image_recognition_subreddit.speaker: Sverre Johann Bj√∏rke
image_recognition_subreddit.title: Image recognition on a subreddit in order to test a suspicion
image_recognition_subreddit.description: After spending too many hours on Reddit, a pattern in one of the subreddits I follow seemed to appear. In an attempt to prove my suspicion I was led down the path of image recognition APIs and beyond.

why_i_fell_in_love_with_elm.speaker: Tale Prestmo
why_i_fell_in_love_with_elm.title: Why I fell in love with Elm
why_i_fell_in_love_with_elm.description: As a developer with minimal experience with functional programming and front-end, I decided to learn Elm. This talk gives an easy introduction to the language, and shows some reasons as to why I enjoy writing code in Elm.

lei_av_darlige_repl.speaker: Alexander Premer
lei_av_darlige_repl.title: Lei av din d√•rlige REPL?
lei_av_darlige_repl.description: Er du en av de som skriver feil i blant? Er litt usikker noen ganger? Liker konfigurerbarhet? Nysgjerrig p√• Scala? Lei av din Scala-REPL?Om minst et av disse utsagnene passer deg, da har du noe du kan ta med deg fra denne talken! Denne talken tar p√• seg oppgaven med √• demonstrere at Scala-REPL er en antikvitet i forhold til Ammonite-REPL!

ui_test_automation.speaker: Christopher Olsen
ui_test_automation.title: UI Test Automation - how and why YOU should start automation on your project!
ui_test_automation.description: An introduction to the field of UI test automation with an emphasize on encouraging people with no experience other than programming knowledge to try and pick up this ball in their projects. All thats needed is knowing where to start and how it fits into your project.

identity_providers_owin_episerver.speaker: H√•vard Eidheim
identity_providers_owin_episerver.title: Multiple Identity providers with OWIN and  Episerver
identity_providers_owin_episerver.description: A presentation on how to set up one or more identity providers with OWIN and Episerver, why you might want to do this and some technical details on how to get it done.

recommendations_recurrent_neural_network.speaker: Ole Steinar Lillest√∏l Skrede
recommendations_recurrent_neural_network.title: Recommendations with Recurrent Neural Networks
recommendations_recurrent_neural_network.description: Research in recent years has shown that recurrent neural networks (RNN) can outperform other state-of-the-art recommendation models at session-based recommendations. This talk is about how RNNs can be used in this domain, and why they work so well.

progressive_web_apps.speaker: Sigurd Christensen
progressive_web_apps.title: Intro til Progressive Web Apps
progressive_web_apps.description: Lag nye web-applikasjoner som direkte kan lastes ned p√• enheter, bli listet p√• Google Play, ha offline-funksjoner eller masse annet - alt dette uten √• r√∏re et native eller hybrid app-rammeverk. Progressive Web Apps holder p√• √• vokse frem som et raskt og enkelt alternativ til dedikerte mobil-apper der man ikke har behov for native APIer. Det er under aktiv utvikling fra flere av de st√∏rste browser og app-akt√∏rene og mulighetene med denne teknologien ser ut til √• utvides raskt. Noe av det beste? Det er fort gjort √• legge til p√• en eksisterende web-app, liten eller stor. I denne talken tar vi en rask kikk p√• hva Progressive Web Apps er og hva man kan bruke det til. I tillegg tar vi en snikkikk p√• hva fremtiden kan by p√• for denne lovende m√•ten √• forbedre web-applikasjoner p√•.

blockchain_hyperledger_fabric.speaker: Anders Breivik
blockchain_hyperledger_fabric.title: Lag din egen blockchain med Hyperledger Fabric
blockchain_hyperledger_fabric.description: Blockchain er teknologien bak Bitcoin, og hevdes √• v√¶re like transformerende som Internet, men hvordan skal du som utvikler klare √• se gjennom all hypen? Gjennom √• lage din egen Blockchain selvsagt! For en utvikler kan teknologist√∏tten for Blockchain-utvikling f√∏les som en tidsmaskin tilbake til 90-tallet. Rammeverk, verkt√∏y og testbarhet er lagt fra modne, og dette utgj√∏r en h√∏y terskel for √• komme i gang med utvikling og prototyping. Hyperledger Fabric er et open source samarbeidsprosjekt med mange akt√∏rer fra blant annet finans og IT, inkludert IBM. IBM tilbyr ""Blockchain as a Service"" basert p√• Hyperledger og utgj√∏r en fin plattform for √• komme i gang med Blockchain-utvikling. Jeg skal vise deg hvordan du kan implementere din egen private Blockchain med Hyperledger Fabric, og hvordan du kommer kjapt i gang med modellering av nettverk og logikk i Hyperledger Composer.

this_keyword_in_javascript.speaker: Alexander Bjerkan
this_keyword_in_javascript.title: The 'this' keyword in JavaScript
this_keyword_in_javascript.description: The 'this' keyword in JavaScript is a bit of a mystery, especially if you have background from other languages. During this talk we'll cover how 'this' works so you'll avoid the most common pitfalls and sources of confusion

android_architecture_components.speaker: Andreas F√¶r√∏vig Olsen
android_architecture_components.title: Android Architecture Components
android_architecture_components.description: Android Architecture Components is a framework for implementing a recommended app architecture. How can this help us improve the quality of our Android apps?

koden_betyr_ingenting.speaker: Astrid Tessem
koden_betyr_ingenting.title: Koden din betyr ingenting
koden_betyr_ingenting.description: Nesten 3/4 av alle klikk p√• s√∏keresultater fra Google g√•r til de fem √∏verste treffene. 1/3 av alle klikk g√•r til det f√∏rste s√∏keresultatet. Koden din kan v√¶re s√• smud du bare vil, men uten god SEO har den ingen betydning. Allmektige Google lar siden din drukne om du ikke er lydig. Dette inneb√¶rer mye mer enn √• legge til riktige redirects og passende n√∏kkelord. N√• til dags m√• vi tilgjengeliggj√∏re dataene v√•re p√• en strukturert m√•te. For du skj√∏nner, Google skal ikke bare indeksere siden din, Google skal FORST√Ö siden din.

intro_to_vuejs.speaker: Aulon Mujaj
intro_to_vuejs.title: Intro to Vue.js
intro_to_vuejs.description: In this talk I'll introduce the vuejs framwork. How does it work, and how extremely easy it is to set up a new project using vuejs. And in the end, discuss the difference between vuejs and react

intro_domenedreven_utvikling.speaker: Beate_Baier Biribakken
intro_domenedreven_utvikling.title: Intro til domenedreven utvikling
intro_domenedreven_utvikling.description: Introduksjon til domenedreven utvikling. Hva er det? Hva er det ikke? Hvorfor b√∏r man bruke det? N√•r kan man bruke det?

machine_learning_open_hotel.speaker: David Svensson
machine_learning_open_hotel.title: Using Machine Learning  to Find Where to Open Our Next Hotel
machine_learning_open_hotel.description: Knowit Analytics Lab has worked on a machine learning prototype with one of the largest hotel chains in the Nordics. The question was ""Where should we open our next hotel"". Or more specifically, ""Can we use machine learning to find locations where a new hotel would be profitable?"". The answer is YES. This session is a technical walk-through covering all aspects of the project - From problem statement and data collection to applied machine learning and visualization of the results.

css_grid.speaker: Filip Egge
css_grid.title: CSS Grid
css_grid.description: CSS Grid ER fremtiden, og fremtiden er her. L√¶r √• ta i bruk grid for din applikasjon.

centralized_logging.speaker: Fredrik Claesson
centralized_logging.title: Centralized (and structured) logging with Serilog + Elastic
centralized_logging.description: Centralized logging isn't only about having all the logs in one place (which will be a mess). In this session I'll talk about some best practices and how Serilog can help you achieve success.

azure_b2c_identity_services.speaker: H√•vard Slettvold
azure_b2c_identity_services.title: Azure AD B2C - identity services done easy
azure_b2c_identity_services.description: The past few years we have seen an increase in demand for identity providers (idp) to take over the task of the humble login form. Many good solutions have surfaced, but one of the best I've ever tried must be Azure AD B2C. A good implementation which supports the entire .Net platform and combines easily with Active Directory, all hosted in the cloud, this identity provider makes development and maintaining a breeze!

mikrotjenester_cdc.speaker: Henrik Stene
mikrotjenester_cdc.title: Deploy microservices confidently using Consumer Driven Contracts
mikrotjenester_cdc.description: Consumer Driven Contracts is a testing paradigm that let API-consumers communicate to the API-providers how they are using their services. This talk discusses software testing, how and when to use Consumer Driven Contract, and how Consumer Driven Contracts can make developers more confident. It also includes live coding to show how to implement Consumer Driven Contracts using the Pact framework. To increase the velocity and reduce the cost of microservices development, it is key to be able to build and deploy new versions with confidence that you don't break any dependencies. Microservices are easy to build and run, but they quickly become a tangled web of dependencies that slow down development and result in broken dependencies. Organizations that transition from a traditional monolithic design to a microservice architecture, will soon realize that it is hard to keep track of all dependencies. Consumer Driven Contracts is a testing paradigm that helps developers keep control on all dependencies in a distributed system and this talk will tell more about how to use it and show how to do so in a live demo.

machine_learning_challenges.speaker: Ivan Starenius
machine_learning_challenges.title: Machine Learning, Challenges and Approaches.
machine_learning_challenges.description: Machine Learning is all the rage. But how does one apply these exciting, powerful techniques in a responsible, sustainable and ""scientific"" way? Having a well thought out and flexible approach to selecting data (features, train/test/validate) and the appropriate algorithms can make all the difference when applying and deploying Machine Learning to real world applications... In this talk we will make a case for why this is so important and try to provide a baseline for how to do it.

iot_fr√•n_grunden.speaker: Jon Johnson
iot_fr√•n_grunden.title: IoT fr√•n grunden - s√• bygger du en internetuppkopplad lampa
iot_fr√•n_grunden.description: Jag kommer att visa hur enkelt det √§r att modda t.ex. en lampa, koppla den till en mikrokontroller och koppla upp den p√• n√§tet. Mikrokontrollers s√•som Arduino eller ESP8266 √§r billiga och enkla att komma ig√•ng med, och kan anv√§ndas s√•v√§l f√∂r sp√§nnande hobbyprojekt som f√∂r att bygga prototyper till verkliga IoT-projekt.

microservices_is_it_worth_it.speaker: Krister Karto
microservices_is_it_worth_it.title: Microservices - is it really worth it
microservices_is_it_worth_it.description: Microservices has been the talk of the town for a little while now, but Microservices is a fancy new concept and it has been around for a while. There are also many benefits of Microservices that has been covered in many talks and articles. However, is MicroServices really worth the effort? In this talk we will draw from lessons learned across several MicroService projects in Knowit, look at the percieved benefits we get from this style of architecture and see if we are actually utilizing those benefits. We will also look at the pains that one get from a MicroService architecture and see if the actual benefits we get outweigh the pains.

role_based_security_with_power_bi.speaker: Magnus S√∂derberg
role_based_security_with_power_bi.title: Role based security with Power BI
role_based_security_with_power_bi.description: In this presentation we will take a closer look at a few different scenarios how an organization can distribute reports and dashboards within Power BI with role based security. This kind of implementation enables large organizations to have a set of common reports but making sure that report consumers only sees what they are supposed/allowed to see.

tfs_og_octopus.speaker: Martin Langtvet
tfs_og_octopus.title: TFS og Octopus - h√•nd i h√•nd
tfs_og_octopus.description: Gjennomgang av hvordan skape smidig l√∏sning for bruk av TFS (team foundation server) sammen med octopus for √• styre alt av builds, kj√∏ring av unittest, kodeanalyse og deployments.

next_microservice_in_go.speaker: Martin Valen
next_microservice_in_go.title: Why your next microservice should be written in Go
next_microservice_in_go.description: Google Go has risen in popularity the last few years. It is perfect for today‚Äôs microservice architecture because of its lightweight design and easy concurrency. At least according to Google. But is it worth the hassle of learning a new language? Is it really as easy to use as they say? Why did Google choose a name for its language that you simply can‚Äôt google? After setting up a few microservices using Go, I can answer at least two of these questions. In this talk you‚Äôll get a short introduction to Go's pros and cons, learn the basics of its syntax, and in the end set up a simple service using Docker.

large_scale_decoupled_torrenting.speaker: Niklas Trippler
large_scale_decoupled_torrenting.title: Large scale decoupled torrenting
large_scale_decoupled_torrenting.description: How well does torrenting scale? How far can the torrent components be spread apart? What will the performance be? Torrenting has been used a long time to share everything from Linux distributions, to game patches and pirated content, and consists of seeders (uploaders), and leechers (downloaders). Seedboxes, that are fast servers for uploading data, are usually dedicated to the purpose with harddrives, torrent clients and networking that are tightly coupled together. I will talk about how to construct a decentralized system where the data, the torrent clients and the networking is hosted at three different locations, using VPNs to create virtual clouds to seed torrents, and which advantages that gives over traditional seedboxes. This talk will show you how to use ZFS, VPNs, containers, VMs and multiple servers to build a distributed file sharing platform where all components are decoupled and can be moved from one site to another in seconds.

error_handling_javascript.speaker: √òyvind Marthinsen
error_handling_javascript.title: Error handling in JavaScript
error_handling_javascript.description: Norsk: I denne presentasjonen gjennomg√•r jeg hvordan du kan rapportere b√•de h√•ndterte og uh√•ndterte feil i JavaScript, til en backend. Jeg fokuserer p√• hvordan vi kan fange uh√•ndterte feil, hvordan hente ut mest mulig informasjon fra disse feilene (f.eks. stacktraces), hvilken annen informasjon som kan v√¶re nyttig √• rapportere og i tillegg viser jeg noen farlige fallgruver. Presentasjonen avsluttes med en demonstrasjon av hvordan man kan bruke source maps for √• sl√• opp hvor feilen oppsto i kildekoden. Engelsk: In this presentation I‚Äôll walk you through how to report both handled and unhandled errors in JavaScript, to a backend. I will focus on how we can capture unhandled errors, how to extract the most information from these errors (such as stack traces), highlight other useful information to report. In addition I'll show some dangerous pitfalls. The presentation ends with a demonstration of how to use source maps to determine where the error occurred in the source code.

chaos_engineering_101.speaker: Petter Barvik
chaos_engineering_101.title: Chaos Engineering 101
chaos_engineering_101.description: This talk will introduce you to the concepts around Chaos Engineering and how this can benefit your applications.

wcag2.0_accessibility_and_frontend.speaker: Sigurd Wahl
wcag2.0_accessibility_and_frontend.title: The accessible web - a talk on WCAG2.0, accessibility and frontend in modern applications
wcag2.0_accessibility_and_frontend.description: The accessible web - a talk on WCAG2.0, accessibility and frontend in modern applications

in_rust_i_trust.speaker: Sverre Johann Bj√∏rke
in_rust_i_trust.title: In Rust I Trust
in_rust_i_trust.description: Rust is a systems programming language that tries to combine the holy trifecta of memory safety, concurrency, and blazing fast speed. Voted the most loved language in Stack Overflows developer survey two years in a row, it combines the performance of low-level languages with high level abstractions, a great package manager and other modern comforts. In this presentation I will talk about what makes Rust a language worth exploring, and will showcase its highlights with some code examples.

how_i_built_a_power_meter.speaker: Thomas Malt
how_i_built_a_power_meter.title: How I built a power meter reader, micro service, docker container, API gateway for my house
how_i_built_a_power_meter.description: How can you stay technologically up to date as a CTO? Working on a strategy to modernise the technology stack at the company I worked I build a proof of concept api gateway, interfacing the electricity meter at my house to create a proof of concept API-first architecture. This talk is about how I did that, the technology I used and why.

smertefri_frontend_testing.speaker: Eirik V√•geskar
smertefri_frontend_testing.title: Smertefri frontend-testing med Cypress
smertefri_frontend_testing.description: Skriver du frontend-tester og synes det er tungtvint? Har du aldri pr√∏vd? Har du pr√∏vd og gitt opp? Om du svarte ja p√• minst ett av disse sp√∏rsm√•lene, burde du pr√∏ve Cypress: Et nytt testrammeverk som installeres og settes opp med √©n kodelinje (spoiler: det er `npm install cypress`) og som kan teste hva som helst som kj√∏rer p√• webben. (Og til de som m√•tte lure: Nei, det har ingenting med Selenium Webdriver √• gj√∏re.) I dette foredraget vil Eirik V√•geskar, som har jobbet i Knowit Objectnet siden h√∏sten 2017, vise deg hvordan man setter opp og bruker Cypress. Han kommer ogs√• til √• fortelle om hvordan billett- og arrangementssystemet Hoopla har tatt i bruk Cypress for √• utvikle og produksjonssette ny funksjonalitet raskere og med st√∏rre selvtillit. Ingen forkunnskaper om automatisk testing er n√∏dvendig. Passer for utviklere av alle ferdighetsniv√•er.

cryptography_illustrated.speaker: Hannah Hansen
cryptography_illustrated.title: Cryptography Illustrated
cryptography_illustrated.description: Are you curious about how messages are kept secret in this digital world? Do bullet points and lectures bore you? Fear not. This talk will temporarily satisfy your curiosity without bullet points. Everything will be illustrated. No text. It will be a fun challenge. Come and see if I manage to convey the topic to your satisfaction. No previous knowledge required. This is a talk for all who wish to learn about public-key cryptography.

doobie_database_access.speaker: Imre Kerr
doobie_database_access.title: Doobie - Principled Database Access for an Unprincipled World
doobie_database_access.description: Functional programming teaches us that immutability, side-effect-free code and determinism are Good Things. But in the land of databases, mutability, side effects and nondeterminism are a fact of life. We will look at how these differences can be reconciled, using Doobie - a database access library for Scala.

not_suck_bootstrap_css.speaker: Patrick T√∏rresvold
not_suck_bootstrap_css.title: How not to suck at Bootstrap.css
not_suck_bootstrap_css.description: How should you really use Bootstrap as a developer or designer? Change your mindset and learn how I want you to use third party frameworks like Bootstrap to improve your daily work.

in_memory_database_testing_ef.speaker: Endre Vestb√∏
in_memory_database_testing_ef.title: In-memory database for black box testing using Entity Framework and Effort
in_memory_database_testing_ef.description: This presentation will show you how to use Effort to create an in-memory database for blackbox testing using Entity Framework. Inlcuding the different ways Effort can be used and how to seemlessly add Effort to your projects using dependency injection.

ai_guided_software_testing.speaker: Juhani Teeriniemi
ai_guided_software_testing.title: AI-Guided Software Testing
ai_guided_software_testing.description: It has been estimated that software bugs cost $59.5 billion annually in U.S. alone. To diminish costs of a software development life cycle, software testing activities should be focused on critical areas of an application. Recently, machine learning methods have been discovered as a powerful tool for software testers. In this presentation, current state of AI-guided software testing is outlined. Also, machine learning based code quality metrics are demonstrated.

agile_development_at_scale.speaker: Thomas Malt
agile_development_at_scale.title: Agile Development at Scale With Autonomous Teams
agile_development_at_scale.description: In this talk the speakers aim to share some of their experiences and observations from the last 10 - 15 years. On how we can create self organising cross functional product development teams, and an organisation where people continuously learn, adapt and innovate. They will try to distill some advice and best practices on what works and what doesn‚Äôt, based on experience and known research.

azure_machine_learning.speaker: Zeeshan Ahmed
azure_machine_learning.title: Azure Machine Learning
azure_machine_learning.description: In this session I will discuss: - What is Machine Learning. - What are the important pre-steps that are needed before getting into the Machine learning itself. - Why we need Machine Learning. -  How we can create Machine Learning models using Azure Machine Learning Studio.  (Demo) -  How we can deploy AML model as web service and use it in custom our applications.  (Demo)

intro_to_angular.speaker: Alf Hammerseth
intro_to_angular.title: Intro to Angular
intro_to_angular.description: Introducing angular and creating a to do list. In this workshop we will demonstrate how easy it is to get up and running with Angular and create your first application. Then we will move on to make a ToDo list with a JSON backend. This is not ment to be a code along course but more a demo of how to get started. You as a participant will observe the magic. There will be an extended time for questions.

angular_warstories.speaker: Alf Hammerseth
angular_warstories.title: Angular Warstories
angular_warstories.description: Talk related to Angular2+ and presenting two cases with the good and the bad.

git_to_find_bugs.speaker: Christoffer Eliesen
git_to_find_bugs.title: How to use Git to help you find bugs
git_to_find_bugs.description: Git has become an important tool for many of us during our daily work. Some people only use it to share code with other developers, but it is actually a really powerful tool and it can help you during your coding sessions too. In this talk I demonstrate some tricks that will allow you to use git to actually help you find bugs while you are coding. Most of the talk will consist of live demonstrations.

devops_maturity_models_knowit_and_dasa_v.speaker: Kari Kakkonen
devops_maturity_models_knowit_and_dasa_v.title: DevOps maturity models Knowit and DASA views
devops_maturity_models_knowit_and_dasa_v.description: DevOps introduction. *Business benefits. *Terminology, e.g. Continuous Delivery. *Faster feedback. *Automate everything you can. DevOps Culture. *DASA DevOps principles. Organization. *Lean & Agile- *Autonomous teams. *Microservices and Cloud. DevOps Maturity. *Step by Step to DevOps. *Maturity Model

securing_azure_active_directory.speaker: Krister Karto
securing_azure_active_directory.title: Securing your application with Azure Active Directory using OAuth.
securing_azure_active_directory.description: Setting up authentication can be a daunting task for developers. What is Audience? What is a token? Where do I do what? In this talk we will cover how to secure a Javsacript frontend, backend services and how to do service-to-service authentication the modern way without creating a system user. We will also show how to setup custom login pages. We will be focusing on using .Net and Microsoft technology, but will be covering the basics around how this works behind the scenes and the basic ideas can be used for different technologies. This talk will be based around real life experience using the .net framework and Azure AD to secure an application that is in production today.

chrome_devtools.speaker: Michael Johansen
chrome_devtools.title: Chrome DevTools
chrome_devtools.description: In technical talks one usually hears a lot about libraries and frameworks. And that is natural. However, we need more talks about tooling and workflow. So this talk will be about Chrome DevTools. The tools people use, and the way the use them, can vary a lot. Experienced developers often take their tools and workflows for granted, while new developers don't know what they're missing before they stand behind you at work, wondering how you did something. We will go in depth on some features of Chrome DevTools that even daily users of the tool may have missed.

improving_marketing_efforts.speaker: Sondre Dyvik
improving_marketing_efforts.title: Improving marketing efforts through clever use of data
improving_marketing_efforts.description: Big data, AI, Machine Learning, IoT, Cloud and Analytics are amongst the hottest buzzwords of 2017. There seems to be a common agreement that these things will revolutionize just about everything, yet it's hard to find good examples of how they're actually being used for marketing. It can be difficult to navigate your way through this blur of buzzwords, and you may wonder:  How big is big data? What's the difference between AI and clever use of data?  Let's put all the semantics aside and talk about how you can improve marketing efforts with data that is big enough through techniques that are intelligent enough.

think_can_frontend.speaker: H√•vard Olsen
think_can_frontend.title: So you think you can frontend?
think_can_frontend.description: As a developer in 2018, you make amazing and impressive solutions, but what happens when we strip away all those ""fancy pants"" tools & frameworks that you love so much? Can you make a website without emmet, sass/less, and without watching your own work along the way? We are hosting a ""Coding in the dark"" competition with a small twist. The competition involves creating a website using a simple editor and a desired endresult. Your task is to make a website described by our designer. Only he knows how the endresult should look like, and you will all be left ""in the dark"" until the end of the workshop. In this workshop your frontend skills as well as your ability to communicate with a UX-designer will be tested. The winner will be announced at the end of the workshop, and in addition to fame & glory, will receive an amazing price!

flexbox_the_right_way.speaker: Patrick Monslaup
flexbox_the_right_way.title: Flexbox - Responsive web made easy
flexbox_the_right_way.description: This workshop will teach you how to quickly create powerful and responsive web components using flexbox. Flexbox is a html5 / css3 property which is finally becoming mature enough that most projects not only can, but should use it. I will in this presentation share my best tips and design patterns, while outlining potential pitfalls that you'll come across when using flex. The workshop features a a short presentation followed by progressively harder components, which should present both fledling web-developer and more experienced code-monkeys a challenge. Requirement to participate is a laptop (or a partner with one), any code editor, and preferably several browser installed such as IE / Safari, Firefox, and Chrome.

mini_economy_blockchain_ethereum_solidit.speaker: Sigurd Lund
mini_economy_blockchain_ethereum_solidit.title: Learn how to build a mini economy on the blockchain by using Ethereum and Solidity!
mini_economy_blockchain_ethereum_solidit.description: Blockchain has existed since Bitcoin was launched in 2009, are now more hyped than ever before. In this workshop we will show you how to write and run code on the Ethereum blockchain. The goal is that within four hours we will develop and deploy a mini economy system where we generate coins that we can send between verified users with smart contracts on Ethereum. The technologies you will use in this workshop will be the Ethereum network, the programming language Solidity, the framework Truffle, and the Ethereum browser Mist. Tests are written to test the functionality to be implemented, so if you like to see the tests go from red to green, this is the workshop for you!
